cards.back: The spontaneous emission of particles or energy from an unstable atomic nucleus.
A helium nucleus ($^4_2He$ or $^4_2\alpha$) consisting of 2 protons and 2 neutrons; low penetrating power, stopped by paper.
A high-energy electron ($^0_{-1}e$ or $^0_{-1}\beta$) emitted when a neutron converts to a proton; moderate penetrating power, stopped by aluminum.
A positive electron ($^0_{+1}e$ or $^0_{+1}\beta$) emitted when a proton converts to a neutron; moderate penetrating power.
High-energy electromagnetic radiation ($^0_0\gamma$) with no mass or charge; very high penetrating power, requires lead or concrete to stop.
The nucleus loses 2 protons and 2 neutrons; mass number decreases by 4, atomic number decreases by 2. Example: $^{238}_{92}U \rightarrow ^{234}_{90}Th + ^4_2He$
A neutron converts to a proton and an electron is emitted; mass number unchanged, atomic number increases by 1. Example: $^{14}_6C \rightarrow ^{14}_7N + ^0_{-1}e$
A proton converts to a neutron and a positron is emitted; mass number unchanged, atomic number decreases by 1. Example: $^{11}_6C \rightarrow ^{11}_5B + ^0_{+1}e$
An excited nucleus releases energy as a gamma ray; no change in mass number or atomic number, only energy state changes.
A process where an inner electron is captured by the nucleus, converting a proton to a neutron; atomic number decreases by 1. Example: $^{40}_{19}K + ^0_{-1}e \rightarrow ^{40}_{18}Ar$
The time required for half of the nuclei in a radioactive sample to decay.
$N_t = N_0 e^{-kt}$ or $\ln\left(\frac{N_t}{N_0}\right) = -kt$ where $N_t$ is the amount remaining at time $t$, $N_0$ is the initial amount, and $k$ is the decay constant.

cards.front: What is the relationship between **half-life and decay constant**?

cards.back: The splitting of a heavy nucleus into two lighter nuclei, releasing a large amount of energy and neutrons. Example: $^{235}_{92}U + ^1_0n \rightarrow ^{141}_{56}Ba + ^{92}_{36}Kr + 3^1_0n$
The combining of two light nuclei to form a heavier nucleus, releasing energy. Example: $^2_1H + ^3_1H \rightarrow ^4_2He + ^1_0n$ (occurs in the sun)
A self-sustaining series of nuclear fission reactions where neutrons from one fission trigger additional fissions.
The minimum mass of fissionable material needed to sustain a chain reaction.
The difference between the mass of a nucleus and the sum of the masses of its individual protons and neutrons.
The energy required to separate a nucleus into its individual protons and neutrons; equivalent to the mass defect via $E = mc^2$.
$E = mc^2$ where $E$ is energy, $m$ is mass, and $c$ is the speed of light; describes the conversion between mass and energy in nuclear reactions.
An element with an atomic number greater than 92 (uranium); all are synthetic and radioactive.
A method of determining the age of organic materials by measuring the ratio of $^{14}C$ to $^{12}C$; based on the half-life of $^{14}C$ (5730 years).
The region on a graph of neutrons vs. protons where stable nuclei are found; unstable nuclei undergo decay to reach this region.
Heavy nuclei (Z > 83) with too many protons and neutrons undergo alpha decay to reduce both.
Nuclei with too many neutrons relative to protons (high n/p ratio) undergo beta-minus decay to convert a neutron to a proton.

cards.front: What ratio favors **positron emission or electron capture**?
cards.back: Nuclei with too many protons relative to neutrons (low n/p ratio) undergo positron emission or electron capture to convert a proton to a neutron.
